metadata.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant company, the assessee, is incorporated in the United Kingdom under the English Companies Act and has its registered office in London.
It owns a spinning and weaving mill at Pondicherry in French India where it manufactures yarn and cloth.

Messrs. Best and Co., Ltd., Madras, have been appointed the agents of the assessee under an agreement dated July 11, 1939, and have been invested with full powers in connection with the business of the assessee in the matter of purchasing stock, signing bills and other negotiable instruments and receipts and settling, compounding or compromising any claim by or against the assessee.
The yarn and cotton manufactured in Pondicherry were sold mostly in British India and partly outside British India.
In the accounting years 1941 and 1942 all the contracts in respect of the sales in British India were entered into in British India and the deliveries were made payments received in British India.
In regard to the sales outside British India also, payments in respect of such sales were received in Madras through the said agents.
The total sales of the goods in the assessment year 1942-43 were Rs. 69,69,145 and for the assessment year 1943-44 were Rs. 93,48,822.
The value of the sales in British India amounted to Rs. 57,07,431 for the assessment year 1942-43 and to Rs. 67,98,356 for the assessment year 1943-44.
The value of the total sales outside British India amounted to Rs. 12,61,714 for the year 1942-43 and Rs. 25,50,472 for the year 1943-44.

Out of the said amounts received in respect of the foreign sales the amounts received in British India were Rs. 9,62,434 for 1942-43 and Rs. 75,230 for 1943-44 and the amounts received outside British India were Rs. 2,99,280 for 1942-43 and Rs. 24,75,242 for 1943-44.

The Income-tax Officer found that the assessee was resident in British India within the meaning of Section 4A(c)(b) of the Act by reason of its income arising in British India in the year of account exceeding its income arising without British India and assessed the company for the two assessment years 1942-43 and 1943-44 on total income both within and without British India under Section 4(1)(b)(i) and (ii) of the Act.
The order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
The order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was confirmed by the Appellate Tribunal on May 15, 1946.
The assessee applied to the Appellate Tribunal under Section 66(1) of the Act for reference to the High Court of certain questions of law arising out of its order.
The Commissioner of Income-tax suggested two questions for reference.
The Appellate Tribunal referred three questions to the High Court.
The third question was concluded by Wallace Bros. Co., Ltd. and was not argued before the High Court; High Court held Sections 4(1) and 4A(c)(b) not ultra vires.

Question 1 was reframed by agreement: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case Section 42(1) and (3) of the Act alone and not Section 4 of the Act have application to the income accruing or arising by reason of sales in British India of manufactured goods where the manufacturing process took place outside British India.

Question 2 retained as referred: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the entire profits and gains arising to the assessee company in British India should be taken into account for the purpose of applying the test laid down under Section 4A(c)(b) or only that part of the profits which could be determined after the application of Section 42(3) of the Act as reasonably be attributable to that part of the operations carried on in British India.
High Court answered both questions against the assessee.
Assessee obtained certificate from High Court for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

In reply to notice under Sections 22(2) and 38 for 1942-43, agents submitted return under protest on June 1, 1943, claiming apportionment under Section 42(3) and that company was not resident in British India.

Total world income for year ended December 31, 1941, shown at Rs. 10,23,907; profit at 10% on British India sales Rs. 57,07,431 shown at Rs. 5,70,743, net British India income Rs. 4,58,026 after deductions.

Income-tax Officer held profits arose in country where sales took place, bulk in British India; Section 42(3) applies only to deemed accrual under 42(1), not actual in British India; assessed as resident under 4A(c).
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed, also held liable under 4(1)(a) relying on Pondicherry Railway and Mathias cases.
Appellate Tribunal held Section 42(3) confined to deemed income under 42; confirmed assessment.
Supreme Court on Dec 22, 1952 reframed questions and remanded to High Court.

High Court (Satyanarayana Rao and Balakrishna Ayyar, JJ.) gave opinion on Feb 13, 1953: Q1 negative against assessee; Q2: income received not wholly arise in India, allocation needed per Ahmedbhai principles.
Supreme Court final hearing, appeal allowed on Dec 8, 1953.

legal_issues.text: Whether in view of the finding of fact in this case that the entire profits were received in India and the company is liable to tax under Section 4(1)(a) of the Act, the provisions of Section 42(1) have any relevancy?

Can the income received in India be said to arise in India within the meaning of Section 4A(c)(b) of the Act? If not, should only those profits determined as attributable to the operations carried out in India be taken into account for applying the test laid down in Section 4A(c)(b)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 42(1) and (3) apply to income accruing/arising in British India from sales of goods manufactured outside; apportion profits under 42(3) for residency test under 4A(c)(b); company not resident as BI income does not exceed outside.
Profits do not wholly arise at place of sale; apportion between manufacturing (Pondicherry) and sales (BI); purchase operations in BI via agents also apportionable.

respondent_arguments.text: If taxed under 4(1)(a) on receipt in BI, Section 42(1) irrelevant as it applies only to deemed accrual; no apportionment under 42(3).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1)(a), Turner Morrison, Hira Mills, Burugu Nagayya

respondent_arguments.text: Entire profits arise in BI as sales and receipts there; no apportionment for 4A(c)(b); Ahmedbhai limited to Excess Profits Tax Act via s.42(3), not general principle; 'arise' in 4A(c)(b) means receivable after all operations.

court_reasoning.text: Where assessment under s.4(1)(a) on actual receipt, s.42(1) irrelevant as it deems accrual from BI business connection; no need for fiction; s.42(3) apportionment not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confirmed by Turner Morrison; applies to residents/non-residents.

court_reasoning.text: Income received in BI not wholly 'arise' in BI under 4A(c)(b); apportion on general principles between operations in/out BI (manufacturing outside, sales/receipts inside); not limited to s.42(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Ahmedbhai majority: profits attributable to manufacturing arise at manufacture place; 'accrue/arise' synonymous.

court_reasoning.text: Purchase operations via agents in BI are systematic, profit-contributing operations warranting apportionment.

holdings.text: Question 1 answered in the negative: provisions of Section 42(1) have no relevancy where liable under Section 4(1)(a).

Question 2: The income received in British India cannot be said to wholly arise in India within the meaning of Section 4A(c)(b); allocation required between income arising in/out taxable territories for residency test.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai Co., Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Apportionment of profits in composite business between manufacturing outside BI and sales inside BI on general principles, not just s.42(3); 'accrue/arise' synonymous.

precedents_cited.case_name: Turner Morrison and Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: S.42(1) inapplicable where actual receipt under s.4(1)(a); no apportionment under s.42(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Bros. Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Residency under 4A(c)(b) where major income from country roots company there.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Company v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Income received in BI via agent taxable under receipt basis.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. Diwan Bahadur Mathias
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits received where sale proceeds received.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burugu Nagayya and Rajanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: S.42 inapplicable to actual receipt cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hira Mills Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Cawnpore
Anglo-French Textile Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for chargeability on receipt/accrual/arising; residency test; deemed accrual from BI business connection and apportionment; reference procedure.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Question 1 answered in negative (s.42(1) irrelevant); Question 2 answered that income received in BI does not wholly arise in BI under s.4A(c)(b), requiring allocation of income between operations in/out BI for residency determination.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand answers confirmed in favor of appellant on residency apportionment.

key_quotes.text: "The income received in British India cannot be said to wholly arise in India within the meaning of Section 4A(c)(b) of the Act and that there should be allocation of the income between the various profit producing operations of the company in the light of the principles contained in the judgments in Ahmedbhai Umarbhai's case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court opinion adopted by SC on apportionment for residency.

key_quotes.text: "Profits are not wholly made by the act of sale and do not necessarily accrue at the place of sale... some portion of the profits must necessarily be attributable to the manufacturing process."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from Ahmedbhai for apportionment.

key_quotes.text: "Whether the words derive and produce are or are not synonymous with the words accrue or arise... they seem to denote the same idea or ideas very similar."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Treats 'accrue' and 'arise' as synonymous for apportionment.
